repnme.cdata!:
Vietnam - Irrigation Rehabilitation
            Project; Water Supply Project; Inland Waterways and Port
            Rehabilitation Project; and Coastal Wetlands Protection Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Irrigation
            Rehabilitation Project for Vietnam are as follows: outcome
            was satisfactory; risk to the development outcome was
            moderate; Bank performance was satisfactory; and Borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Ratings for the Water
            Supply Project for Vietnam are as follows: outcome was
            satisfactory; risk to the development outcome was moderate,
            Bank performance was satisfactory; and Borrower performance
            was also satisfactory. Ratings for the Inland Waterways and
            Port Rehabilitation Project for Vietnam are as follows:
            outcome was satisfactory; risk to the development outcome
            was moderate; Bank performance was moderately satisfactory;
            and Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory.
            Ratings for the Coastal Wetlands Protection Project for
            Vietnam are as follows: outcome was satisfactory; risk to
            the development outcome was significant; Bank performance
            was moderately satisfactory; and Borrower performance was
            also moderately satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            projects included: in Vietnam it is increasingly likely that
            projects that build water infrastructure will be called on
            to perform environmental restoration as well as their core
            activities, if they are to have sustainable outcomes. The
            four projects studied share certain characteristics. First
            and foremost is the nature of their relationship to the
            environment. Whereas traditionally Bank water sector
            projects had either an institutional or infrastructure focus
            or both, it is becoming nearly impossible to avoid
            addressing environmental restoration and environmentally
            related land use questions in many areas of the country. In
            the four evaluated projects it was assumed that investments
            in infrastructure will overcome what were in essence
            environmental problems. If all the mangroves have been
            destroyed it is never enough just to plant new ones:
            reforestation and forest protection have to address the
            underlying social causes of encroachment and provide
            alternative sources of income if they hope to stop
            environmentally negative actions that produce income for the
            malefactors. Conversely, addressing livelihood problems can
            have positive environmental impacts.

repnme.cdata!:
Vietnam - Inland Waterways and Port
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Inland Waterways and
            Port Rehabilitation Project in Vietnam were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: 1) Differences on matters of policy between the
            Borrower and IDA would best be resolved prior to Board
            presentation; 2) Resettlement in the project took longer to
            complete than expected. Ideally, resettlement should have
            been completed before the award of contracts whose execution
            could be affected by the resettlement process; 3) For future
            dredging operations, it may be helpful to include
            hydrographic surveys in the scope of work of supervision
            consultants. Dredging operations could have been expedited
            if the quality and timeliness of surveys prior to and post
            dredging had been better; 4) Cargo handling facilities
            should be designed not only in accordance with engineering
            standards but to also take into account the services to be
            provided; 5) Competitive Bidding Benefits both Cost and
            Quality; and 6) In the future, modal administrations should
            take a much more central role in managing waterways projects
            and dictating their direction. This would increase ownership
            of the infrastructure and the desire to maintain it.

repnme.cdata!:
Vietnam - Inland Waterways and Port
            Modernization Project : environmental action plan and
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Inland Waterways and Port
            Modernization Project in Vietnam consists of improvements to
            sections of two main waterways south of Ho Chi Minh City and
            within the Mekong River Delta, thus providing for increased
            vessel haulage capacity. Improvements to Can Tho Port will
            provide for better cargo handling, cargo storage, and
            treatment/disposal of ship wastes. This environmental
            assessment evaluates adverse biophysical impacts related to
            project activities both during construction and operation
            phases; presents mitigation measures to reduce both
            predicted and actual impacts; and reports on the
            environmental aspects of the project, including temporary
            and permanent adverse impacts and benefits. During
            construction of the waterway and the Thoi Binh Lock, various
            mitigation measures will be adopted to reduce impacts
            identified as unacceptable, that is, a more than 20 percent
            change in oxygen levels and pH concentrations in the
            waterway; a more than 20 percent change in other critical
            elements (totally suspended liquids, oil or fecal
            coliform-bacteria, and the 5 trace metals) in potable water;
            or a decrease of 2 pH units beyond the normal range in
            aquaculture. Measures include: altering dredging activities
            to reduce release of suspended solids and associated
            contaminants by either reducing dredging intensity; or
            changing dredging operational practices. Dredging of the
            bank of some waterway sections may change the pH of water in
            the channels - this must be considered a residual
            non-mitigable impact. If unacceptable changes also occur in
            the pH of potable water and in water used in aquaculture,
            other options are to modify dredging operational practices,
            to increase monitoring, and to re-evaluate physical soil
            conditions. Actions to mitigate unacceptable changes in the
            normal range of concentrations in dissolved oxygen, total
            suspended liquids, fecal coliform bacteria, or a decrease
            below the normal range of pH concentration will prompt a
            reduction in the rate of water discharge from any or all of
            the water basins. Persistent or abrupt noise exceeding a set
            decibel level will be mitigated by installing additional
            noise dampening on the dredge or the booster pumping
            stations; altering the timing of certain work practices; or
            penalizing the contractor and transferring these funds to
            the community as compensation. The operational phase of the
            waterways and the Thoi Binh Lock will cause increased
            erosion and the collapse of canal banks, with stronger tidal
            effects leading to greater seawater intrusion, significantly
            impacting aquatic and terrestrial ecology (food source loss,
            and destroyed habitats, aquatic plants, and animal species)
            and agriculture, lessening the ability to use canal water
            for other uses, promoting sedimentation, and increasing
            salinity. Canal dredging will increase fresh water from
            upstream, and discharge and acidic and salt water will be
            pushed further downstream, particularly in the wet season.
            Increased vessel traffic will lead to: 1) uncontrolled
            discharge, which will increase existing waste impacts to the
            general aquatic ecosystem of the canals and rivers, coastal
            marine ecosystem and human health of waterway users; and 2)
            increased potential for spillage of petroleum hydrocarbon
            products, such as fuels, hydraulic line oils, etc. Noise
            will be mitigated by controls, such as banning whistles and
            horns or fining vessels with inadequate muffler systems. The
            operational phase of the Can Tho Port will increase noise,
            which will be mitigated by installing upgraded mufflers on
            cranes and vehicles. The port will be required to provide
            facilities to receive and treat oil-contaminated waters,
            chemical-contaminated waters, sanitary sewage, and
            shipwaste. Stormwater drainage will transport surface runoff
            of pollutants into the Bassac River. A resettlement action
            plan conforming to the World Bank's operational
            directive is included.

repnme.cdata!:
Viet Nam - Inland Waterways and Port
            Rehabilitation Project : resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the resettlement action plan
            (RAP) for the Inland Waterways and Port Rehabilitation
            Project, and, aims at ensuring that all project affected
            people (PAP), as of the date of the socioeconomic survey
            (November 1995) will improve, or at least regain their
            standard of living; be relocated as village units, village
            sections, or families, as the case may be; be integrated
            into the community to which they are resettled; be provided
            with appropriate compensation for asset losses at
            replacement costs, as well as with adequate social, and
            physical rehabilitation, infrastructure, including housing
            lots, community services, and facilities; and, participate
            in the design, and implementation of the resettlement
            planning. The RAP is based on the policy on land acquisition
            and resettlement, on the principles of resettlement,
            compensation, and subsidiary policies, on rehabilitation
            assistance for income restoration, and, on public
            participation, consultation and grievance mechanisms, as
            well as on institutional aspects. Compensation shall be
            available for all affected structures, and fixed assets at
            replacement costs without depreciation, to be paid in cash,
            or in kind, in the form of building materials, i.e., bricks,
            cement, etc. Salvageable materials are to be collected by
            PAPs for re-use - no reduction will be made for salvageable
            materials. Individual cases will be ruled by a Resettlement
            and Relocation Committee, and the RAP stipulates that all
            compensation will be paid prior to displacement, subsistence
            allowances will be given, preferably in kind, and job
            training will be imparted to minimize economic hardships on
            displaced families.

            project activities both during construction and operation
            phases; presents mitigation measures to reduce both
            predicted and actual impacts; and reports on the
            environmental aspects of the project, including temporary
            and permanent adverse impacts and benefits. During
            construction of the waterway and the Thoi Binh Lock, various
            mitigation measures will be adopted to reduce impacts
            identified as unacceptable, that is, a more than 20 percent
            change in oxygen levels and pH concentrations in the
            waterway; a more than 20 percent change in other critical
            elements (totally suspended liquids, oil or fecal
            coliform-bacteria, and the 5 trace metals) in potable water;
            or a decrease of 2 pH units beyond the normal range in
            aquaculture. Measures include: altering dredging activities
            to reduce release of suspended solids and associated
            contaminants by either reducing dredging intensity; or
            changing dredging operational practices. Dredging of the
            bank of some waterway sections may change the pH of water in
            the channels - this must be considered a residual
            non-mitigable impact. If unacceptable changes also occur in
            the pH of potable water and in water used in aquaculture,
            other options are to modify dredging operational practices,
            to increase monitoring, and to re-evaluate physical soil
            conditions. Actions to mitigate unacceptable changes in the
            normal range of concentrations in dissolved oxygen, total
            suspended liquids, fecal coliform bacteria, or a decrease
            below the normal range of pH concentration will prompt a
            reduction in the rate of water discharge from any or all of
            the water basins. Persistent or abrupt noise exceeding a set
            decibel level will be mitigated by installing additional
            noise dampening on the dredge or the booster pumping
            stations; altering the timing of certain work practices; or
            penalizing the contractor and transferring these funds to
            the community as compensation. The operational phase of the
            waterways and the Thoi Binh Lock will cause increased
            erosion and the collapse of canal banks, with stronger tidal
            effects leading to greater seawater intrusion, significantly
            impacting aquatic and terrestrial ecology (food source loss,
            and destroyed habitats, aquatic plants, and animal species)
            and agriculture, lessening the ability to use canal water
            for other uses, promoting sedimentation, and increasing
            salinity. Canal dredging will increase fresh water from
            upstream, and discharge and acidic and salt water will be
            pushed further downstream, particularly in the wet season.
            Increased vessel traffic will lead to: 1) uncontrolled
            discharge, which will increase existing waste impacts to the
            general aquatic ecosystem of the canals and rivers, coastal
            marine ecosystem and human health of waterway users; and 2)
            increased potential for spillage of petroleum hydrocarbon
            products, such as fuels, hydraulic line oils, etc. Noise
            will be mitigated by controls, such as banning whistles and
            horns or fining vessels with inadequate muffler systems. The
            operational phase of the Can Tho Port will increase noise,
            which will be mitigated by installing upgraded mufflers on
            cranes and vehicles. The port will be required to provide
            facilities to receive and treat oil-contaminated waters,
            chemical-contaminated waters, sanitary sewage, and
            shipwaste. Stormwater drainage will transport surface runoff
            of pollutants into the Bassac River. A resettlement action
            plan conforming to the World Bank's operational
            directive is included.

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the resettlement action plan
            (RAP) for the Inland Waterways and Port Rehabilitation
            Project, and, aims at ensuring that all project affected
            people (PAP), as of the date of the socioeconomic survey
            (November 1995) will improve, or at least regain their
            standard of living; be relocated as village units, village
            sections, or families, as the case may be; be integrated
            into the community to which they are resettled; be provided
            with appropriate compensation for asset losses at
            replacement costs, as well as with adequate social, and
            physical rehabilitation, infrastructure, including housing
            lots, community services, and facilities; and, participate
            in the design, and implementation of the resettlement
            planning. The RAP is based on the policy on land acquisition
            and resettlement, on the principles of resettlement,
            compensation, and subsidiary policies, on rehabilitation
            assistance for income restoration, and, on public
            participation, consultation and grievance mechanisms, as
            well as on institutional aspects. Compensation shall be
            available for all affected structures, and fixed assets at
            replacement costs without depreciation, to be paid in cash,
            or in kind, in the form of building materials, i.e., bricks,
            cement, etc. Salvageable materials are to be collected by
            PAPs for re-use - no reduction will be made for salvageable
            materials. Individual cases will be ruled by a Resettlement
            and Relocation Committee, and the RAP stipulates that all
            compensation will be paid prior to displacement, subsistence
            allowances will be given, preferably in kind, and job
            training will be imparted to minimize economic hardships on
            displaced families.
